none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, May 22, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, May 22, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 13 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: In this letter dated May 22, 1883, J. T. Hand, superintendent of schools in Corsicana, Texas, writes to Professor Louis L. McInnis about his recent visit with former chancellor P. H. Mell in Waco and the closing of the school year. Hand discusses the success of the schools under his management, the uncertainty of administrative positions in Texas, and his unexpected assignment to speak about George Peabody's life and character at an event in Galveston on June 26th. He also conveys news of his wife's recovery from attending to an ill grandchild and expresses a desire to meet with McInnis for extended conversation.

body.value:
Office of Supt.
Corsicana Tex. May 22 - 1883.

My Dear Professor:

Your valuable letter
of 17th inst recd & read with much interest.
I ran down to Waco last week for
two days to see my old Chancellor,
P.H. Mell, D.D LL.D I had not
seen the grand old man for
27 years - The meeting was one of
no ordinary interest & pleasure to me.
I saw but little change in this
great man, Primus inter illustres,
only he has grown quite grey -
his intellect grand - his scholarship
profound - his piety sublime - his
control of self & men perfect -
Such men are few.

(over)

**Letter Transcription: A Detailed Analysis** Alright, I'm diving into this handwritten letter. Let's start with the heading: "Office of Supt." I need to get this right. Then the location and date, "Corsicana Tex. May 22 - 1883." That's the setup. Okay, the salutation is "My Dear Professor:" – seems formal. Now, let's get into the body: "Your valuable letter
of 17th inst recd & read with much interest." "inst." is abbreviated, so it must be "instant" – meaning the current month. "recd" looks a little messy, but I'm going with "recd" for received. It's common shorthand, and that's how it appears. Next: "I ran down to Waco last week for
two days to see my old Chancellor," – Ah, a personal anecdote. This person is likely important. Let's see... "P.H. Mell, D.D LL.D I had not
seen the grand old man for
27 years - The meeting was one of
no ordinary interest & pleasure to me." The name's important: P.H. Mell, and the degrees. That's Patrick Hues Mell. D.D. and LL.D. – it's crucial to get those degrees right. It looks like "SS.D" but LL.D is more likely. "Primus inter illustres," - he was a famous person. I've got to make sure I get that Latin phrase spelled accurately. It's written as it should be. He continues to describe Mell: "I saw but little change in this
great man, Primus inter illustres,
only he has grown quite grey -
his intellect grand - his scholarship
profound - his piety sublime - his
control of self & men perfect -
Such men are few." – Quite a glowing endorsement. And that wraps it up. Final checks: the letter is written. Here is the full transcription:

Office of Supt.
Corsicana Tex. May 22 - 1883.

My Dear Professor:

Your valuable letter
of 17th inst recd & read with much interest.
I ran down to Waco last week for
two days to see my old Chancellor,
P.H. Mell, D.D LL.D I had not
seen the grand old man for
27 years - The meeting was one of
no ordinary interest & pleasure to me.
I saw but little change in this
great man, Primus inter illustres,
only he has grown quite grey -
his intellect grand - his scholarship
profound - his piety sublime - his
control of self & men perfect -
Such men are few.

(over)

Our Schools close on Friday
25th inst. I think our general
management & methods have given
very general satisfaction. I have
only been solicitous about the
discharge of duty - I leave the
results with God & those interested.
The Schools are a success up to
this time. The Supt of the Schools may
not possess merit - if at all in
small degree - but the Schools
do in large degree. Elections
for another year take place
1st of July - Past experience has
taught me the uncertainty of
position in Texas School tactics.
Nor do I now disturbe myself
much over that subject.
The pecuniary attachment is but
a brittle thread at most & sometimes
we are indifferent whether it

**Transcription Analysis and Refinement** Okay, so I'm tackling this handwritten document. First, the basics: it's a cursive letter on aged paper with dark ink. Legibility is good overall, though some letter formations are a bit loose—like the 't', 'r', and 's'. I'm going line by line, making notes. "Our Schools close on Friday" is pretty straightforward. I'm noting the abbreviation "inst." for "instant"—current month—and I'm pretty certain about "solicitous." "Duty" ends with a dash, so I'll include that. I'm also confirming "Schools" is capitalized, "Supt" is the abbreviation for Superintendent, "possess" is written with a loose cursive or long s notation, and "degree" ends with a dash. I'm paying close attention to the formatting. "1st" looks like "1st", and I will superscript the "st". "Past experience" has an underline, so I'll need to use either `` for italics or maybe `` for the underline, although I should re-check what HTML markup is supported. "Texas" and "tactics" are a bit tricky, but I think they are correct. And "disturbe" has a distinct 'e' at the end. I will transcribe it as "disturbe." The word "pecuniary" is clear. "brittle" is clear. "indifferent" is clear. Now, let's go back and double-check some of those trickier words and confirm everything: Yes, it's definitely "methods." "Solicitous" is correct. "Supt" looks like it's clearly superscript. "Tactics" might look like "tretics" at first, but given the context of "School tactics," "tactics" makes sense. "Disturbe" looks like it's spelled "disturbe," with an 'e'. I'm not overthinking it. The underline on "Past experience" looks like emphasis. Okay, let's keep going. "Our Schools" - looks capitalized. I'm double-checking the superscript 't' and 'h' in "25th." Nope, it's inline. And I will use superscript for the st in 1st. "Methods" is clear. "Tactics" are also clear. Yes, "disturbe" looks like it's spelled "disturbe". "Supt" looks correct. "25th" and "1st" are definitely superscript. "Disturbe" is definitely spelled like that. I am re-evaluating "1st", "methods", "Texas", "tactics", "disturbe." Yes, those are correct. I am re-evaluating the "Supt" abbreviation again. It is not superscript. Yes, the letters make sense, and the words are clear. I will use standard HTML tags for layout like `

Our Schools close on Friday
25th inst. I think our general
management & methods have given
very general satisfaction. I have
only been solicitous about the
discharge of duty - I leave the
results with God & those interested.
The Schools are a success up to
this time. The Supt of the Schools may
not possess merit - if at all in
small degree - but the Schools
do in large degree. Elections
for another year take place
1st of July - Past experience has
taught me the uncertainty of
position in Texas School tactics.
Nor do I now disturbe myself
much over that subject.
The pecuniary attachment is but
a brittle thread at most & sometimes
we are indifferent whether it

[header] [1883, May 22] — 3

"Snap" or not. Without my knowledge
or consent, I have been assigned
to duty at Galveston June 26th to
discuss Life & character of Mr. Peabody —
The assignment seems to be — as
a kind of "tail" to the Kite of
some one else. I suppose all
Kites have tails; and brother
Josh Billings seems to intimate
that a "Caudal Extremity" is a
good institution When he says,
you should always "catch a bull
by the tail & not by the horns".
Well, one can let go with
more safety — besides, it is
an uncivil wind that blows
no good to any one.

**A Deep Dive into a Letter from 1883**

Okay, here's what I've got. The user wants me to render this handwritten text, and I need to be exact. The image presents a letter, likely from May 22nd, 1883, based on the penciled date at the top. It's page 3, underlined, of a larger document. The handwriting is typical of the late 19th century—cursive, a bit flourished. I'll need to transcribe it line by line, paying close attention to every detail: the punctuation, the capitalization, and especially any peculiarities in the lettering.

First, the header: `[1883, May 22] — 3`. Then I start reading the first line: `"Snap" or not. Without my knowledge`. Interesting, with the quotes. Let's see how that develops... The second line follows: `or consent, I have been assigned`. I'm starting to get a sense of the writer's tone. Next, `to duty at Galveston June 26<sup>th</sup> to`. Okay, so there's an assignment to Galveston...and the date's superscript, I'll keep it as it's written. Next, `discuss Life & character of Mr. Peabody —`. Looks like an ampersand, but needs a closer look, the style is a bit peculiar. Alright, I've got it - a `&`. Also, the dash at the end of the line, got it.

`The assignment seems to be — as`. Okay. A dash in the sentence. Next line: `a kind of "tail" to the Kite of`. The "tail" is in quotes, a metaphor, I'll transcribe them as they are. This is getting interesting. What does this mean? `some one else. I suppose all`. It all fits with the style. Then, `Kites have tails; and brother`. Looks like a semicolon there. Then, `Josh Billings seems to intimate`. Josh Billings, that name I'm familiar with, a famous humorist of the era, so I'll put it in. Here it gets complicated. The next line is `that a "Caudal Extremity" is a`. "Caudal Extremity" again, in quotes. A bit of wordplay, I reckon.

Then `good institution When he says,`. The mystery letter: Is it `says`? Or something else? The context favors "says," and that's the common form for the quotes. But, still... The handwriting is a little obscure. Let's dig deeper: Is it `says`? Does it look like `bays`? `trays`? No, let's keep it as `says`.

Then, `you should always "catch a bull`. Ah, the famous Billings quote! I'll transcribe this as: `by the tail & not by the horns".`. Then: `Well, one can let go with`. Then, `more safety — besides, it is`. A dash again. Then: `an uncivil wind that blows`. Ah hah! Not "evil," but "uncivil"—a pun, a play on the saying. Let me transcribe this as `uncivil`. The final line: `no good to any one.`.

Now to double check everything. The quotes, the dates, the names, the ampersands, and particularly any ambiguous words. Everything seems correct, the punctuation, the spacing, the capitalization. The letter seems solid.

4

Mrs. Hana has been absent near
three weeks - waiting at the Couch
of a sick grandchild - seemingly
at least, just on the border of the
eternal world. We have a letter from
her this morning, conveying the
glad intelligence that the little
child has passed the crisis + will
recover - if no relapse.
I shall be to glad to see you - if you
can run up to our place.
I am quite anxious to have some
long talks with you. Had a
letter from Capt J G Fowlks a
few days ago - En route to Galveston
I would like to stop off a little at
Arme if in "accordance with the
eternal fitness of things"
Write quite soon.

Your friend
I. T. Hana

**Detailed Transcription Analysis and Refinement**

Okay, here’s my analysis. I'm tasked with transcribing this handwritten letter, and I’m approaching it systematically. The initial assessment indicates it's likely late 19th or early 20th-century cursive, and there’s a distinct “4” in the top right, probably a page number. The content seems to revolve around a personal letter discussing a Mrs. Hana (or Hanna - I’m working that out) and a sick grandchild, with a possible visit.

Line by line, here's what I'm thinking:

1.  The first line introduces Mrs. Hana, which could also be "Hand" or "Hanna". I'm looking closely at the signature at the bottom as a reference and matching the “H” characters. Given what I see I'm pretty sure it's "Hana".
2.  I am carefully looking at the handwriting of the writer to see how the n character is rendered.
3.  The text describes the grandchild's illness as something "bordering the eternal world". This suggests the seriousness of the situation.
4.  Then the letter mentions receiving a letter that morning with glad news.
5.  I need to check for abbreviations or symbols and note any unusual penmanship or word errors.
6.  The writer mentions the grandchild has passed a crisis and might recover. I'm making sure that I handle the symbols and abbreviations (the & symbol).
7.  The writer then hopes to see the person addressed in the letter.
8.  I am now transcribing the sentence "I shall be to glad to see you" from the line "I shall be to glad to see you - if you". The word "to" could be a grammatical error and could mean "so" or "too".
9.  Then a name. Capt. J. G. Fowlks.
10. The text has "En route to Galveston" - common usage.
11. The line "I would like to stop off a little at Arme". "Arme" is the key. I am checking the handwriting of 'A', and looking for similar place names near Galveston. I am questioning "Home" but the writer writes the H. Looking for similar handwriting in the letter. It doesn't look like 'H'. The writer’s use of capital 'A' vs. 'h' or other possibilities must be checked.
12. A review of all handwriting and potential place names must be checked.
13. The text ends with "Write quite soon".
14. The letter is signed "I. T. Hana". I check this against previous use of 'I' and 'T'.
15. I need to handle any sentence structure.
16. The final output is to transcribe the image in a literal manner while handling any ambiguities. I will use the appropriate HTML tags for rendering the text in an accessible format.

I am ready to provide the final transcription.
